Ding contributed equally to this work Single-atom catalysts (SACs) have generated a significant research interest due to the enormous potential of being able to maximize the catalytic activity and efficiency. One synthetic strategy to control the dispersion, loading and surface area of catalyst to enhance catalyst performance is to design a heterogeneous, SAC system. However, the mechanistic control and understanding of catalyst dispersion, size distribution, and stability within a suitable support remains challenging. In this paper, a new strategy was developed for the synthesis of Fenton-like, Co-O-Si SAC by combining sol-gel chemistry and rapid thermal processing for catalytic metal-center anchoring. A high amount of Co metal loading of 16.3 wt% was achieved in a well-integrated, single atom Co-O-Si framework possessing excellent metal ion dispersion without any metal aggregation or metal oxides formation. The obtained Co-O-Si SAC delivered two orders of magnitude higher catalytic activity compared to the other cobalt-based, Fenton nanoparticle catalysts with outstanding reusability and performance stability for the removal of hazardous organic compounds using model antibiotics (oxytetracycline, tetracycline hydrochloride) and synthetic dyes (neutral red, acid orange). The solid heterogeneous catalyst produced by loading metal particles onto various supports is widely applied for the gas and liquid phase reactions because it offers the advantages of catalyst separation and reuse [1–3]. However, the atom utilization efficiency of nanoparticle catalysts is usually low because it is the only available and accessible surface of the catalysts that can engage in the catalytic reaction process. In contrast, the homogenous catalysis process can maximize the catalytic activity of the metal as all the active sites are readily exposed to the reactants, however the regeneration of homogeneous catalyst adds further process complexity in the product-catalyst separation [4–6]. Hence, the research on developing and improving the atom utilization efficiency of heterogeneous catalysts has become a major focus in the field of catalysis. Over the past decade, the field of atomically dispersed, heterogeneous catalyst research has experienced a rapid growth, driven by its potential to attain maximum catalytic activity per atom. This phenomenon has led to a re-evaluation of catalytic efficiency standards, and was thought to be technically impossible twenty years ago when Qiao et al. dispelled the decade-long, skepticism by demonstrating atomically dispersed Pt on FeOx support with excellent CO oxidation [4,7–11] [12]. To date, research advancement and challenges on single-atom catalysts (SACs) synthesis and applications using noble metals (Pt, Ir, Pd, Rh, etc.) and non-noble metals (Fe, Co, Ni, etc.) are comprehensively summarized in a number of recent reviews [8,13,14]. New synthetic strategies have been proposed to stabilize the metal atoms on the support. The metal atoms can be immobilized by the defects of oxides, confined in the pores of zeolites, coordinated with MOFs, and anchored by the heteroatoms in supports such as N, O, and S [10,15–17]. However, the practical applications of SACs still face challenges of low catalyst dispersion and low metal loading, which is a recognized structural trade-off. For example, low metal loading (usually less than 1 wt%) favors catalyst dispersion within the support leading to a low catalytic efficiency. Conversely, by increasing the metal loading, it will cause metal migration and aggregation to form metal oxide clusters or nanoparticles under high temperature which will eventually reduce the overall catalytic efficiency [18]. The low metal concentration of SACs results in the requirement of larger catalyst quantity in order to achieve the desired degree of conversion, but this will inevitably worsen the heat and mass transfer and increase capital cost due to a larger footprint. Therefore, SACs with high metal loading will undoubtedly facilitate practical applications. Recently, a number of papers have reported a breakthrough in increasing the metal loading of SACs [19–23]. For example, the multilayer confinement strategy can produce atomically dispersed Fe, Co, Ru, Ir and Pt catalysts on N, S, and F-co-doped porous graphitized carbon with high metal loading of up to 16 wt% [19]. Using a chelate complex precursor is another method to avoid metal aggregation at elevated temperatures, by which atomically dispersed metal-Nx on carbon support was synthesized with a metal loading of up to 12.1 wt% [20]. In particular, Wang et al.[24] reviewed the recently reported SACs with high metal loadings (>5 wt%), among which more than 80 % of SACs were supported on carbon-based materials sourced from sustainable carbon derivatives. Among the choice of catalyst support, SiO2 is a widely used catalyst support in heterogeneous reaction and separation research because it is cheap, abundant, and readily scalable for industrial deployment. Thus, the development of a scalable method for the fabrication of high-loading metal-SiO2 SACs to achieve maximized efficiency has become paramount. Recent literature has shown that designing SiO2-based inorganic thin films and nanostructure catalytic membrane reactors with embedded or impregnated catalysts can be scaled up using dip-coating, spin-coating or hydrothermal synthesis [25–27]. Moreover, these strategies can enhance the controlled loading of catalysts and accessibility of the catalytic active sites to oxidants in a microreactor environment, while a catalytic top layer consisting of a thin film on a membrane reactor is expected to facilitate the maximization of catalytic efficiency. Although some SACs based on SiO2 supports have recently been reported [8], controlled synthesis of high-metal loading SACs as well as the formation mechanism of catalyst morphology and metal dispersion within the SiO2 support remains technically very challenging. Herein, we report a new strategy for the synthesis of SiO2-supported Co single-atom catalyst by modifying acid-catalyzed sol-gel silica chemistry coupled with a scalable rapid thermal, high temperature processing to promote metal dispersion and suppress metal aggregation. The cobalt atoms are found to be atomically integrated within the Co-O-Si amorphous network with high microporosity and surface areas, leading to a significant metal loading of up to 16.3 wt%. The obtained SAC was evaluated for organic pollutant degradation as an advanced, Fenton-like, oxidation catalyst for wastewater treatment, which displayed superior activity compared to several state-of-the-art cobalt-based catalysts. 2 Methodology 2.1 Materials Cobalt nitrate hexahydrate (Co(NO3)2.6H2O, 98 %, Sigma-Aldrich), ethanol (99 %, Sigma Aldrich), nitric acid (HNO3, 69 %, Supelco) and ethyl silicate (ES40, Wacker), acid orange 7 (AO7, ≥85 %, Sigma-Aldrich), neutral red (NR, ≥90 %, Sigma-Aldrich), tetracycline hydrochloride (TCH, ≥98 %, Cayman), and oxytetracycline (OTC, ≥95 %, Cayman), hydrogen peroxide (30 % w/w, Chem-supply) and sodium bicarbonate (≥99.7 %, MERCK), 5,5-Dimethyl-1-pyrroline N-oxide (DMPO, ≥98.0 %, MERCK) was used without purification. All chemicals were used as received without further purification. 2.2 Catalyst preparation 2.2.1 Preparation of Co-O-Si The preparation method for Co-O-Si catalyst is schematically shown in Fig. S1. Firstly, cobalt nitrate hexahydrate was dissolved in a mixture of deionized water, ethanol, and nitric acid. Ethyl silicate 40 was then added drop-wisely to the mixture under constant stirring. The specific molar composition of SiO2: Co(NO3)2·6H2O: EtOH: H2O: HNO3 of the final mixture was 4: 1: 255: 40: 0.15 respectively. The solution was stirred for 30 min at 30 ℃ before dropping on petri dishes. Subsequently, it was dried at 60 ℃ for 60 min in the oven, and then at 100 ℃ for another 60 min. The dry gel was treated by the rapid thermal process (RTP), i.e., direct calcination in a pre-heated furnace at 600 ℃ for 60 min. After cooling to room temperature, the obtained sample was grounded into fine powder by using agate mortar. The schematic diagram of the catalyst is shown in Fig. 1. For comparison, this work also investigated other cobalt oxide catalysts commonly reported for Fenton-like catalysts, which included Co3O4 on amorphous SiO2, Co3O4 and SiO2 as control. 2.2.2 Preparation of Co3O4, Co3O4 on amorphous SiO2 (Co3O4/SiO2), and SiO2 The Co3O4 catalyst was prepared by the traditional precipitation method, with Co(NO3)2·6 H2O as the cobalt precursor and Na2CO3 as the precipitant [28]. 1 mol L−1 Na2CO3 aqueous solution was added dropwise to 0.5 mol L−1 of Co(NO3)2.6H2O aqueous solution at room temperature until the pH reached 9. After stirring for 60 min, the slurry was filtered and washed thoroughly with deionized water. Then, the sample was dried at 100 ℃ for 12 h, followed by calcination at 500 ℃ in air for 4 h with a heating rate of 2 ℃ min−1. The 25 mol% Co3O4/SiO2 catalyst was prepared by the incipient wetness impregnation method using the obtained SiO2 as support as previously reported [29]. For the control sample, amorphous SiO2 was prepared by the same method as Co-O-Si catalyst described above but without adding the cobalt source, i.e., the specific molar composition of SiO2: EtOH: H2O: HNO3 of the synthesis sol was 4: 255: 40: 0.15 respectively. 2.3 Characterizations Atom probe tomography (APT) measurements were conducted with a CAMECA local electrode atom probe 4000 × Si at a cryogenic temperature of 50 K, using a 355 nm wavelength UV laser. For the APT experiment, the bulk Co-O-Si was firstly prepared and shaped into a nanotip using the tripod polishing method followed by focused ion beam (FIB) milling. The sharpened tip with a diameter of tens of nanometer is shown in Fig. 2a. The experiment was performed in a high vacuum at a cryogenic temperature of 50 K. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM), scanning transmission electron microscopy equipped with high angular annular dark field detector (STEM-HAADF), and energy-dispersive spectroscopy (EDS) mapping images were recorded using an FEI Themis-Z Double-corrected 60–300 kV S/TEM. XRD patterns of the samples were recorded on a Stoe Stadi P powder diffractometer conFig.d with molybdenum X-ray source, as Mo Kα x-ray has a lower detection limit than Cu Kα X-ray source for Co-containing composites. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was carried out on an ESCALAB250Xi spectrometer (Thermo Scientific) with a monochromated Al Kα X-ray radiation source (E = 1486.68 eV). The XPS binding energy was calibrated against the C 1 s peak at 284.8 eV of adventitious carbon The X-ray absorption fine structure (XAFS) measurements of the Co K-edges were collected using the 14W1 beamline of the Shanghai Synchrotron Radiation Facility. Fourier transform infrared-attenuated total reflectance (FTIR-ATR) spectra were collected on a Nicolet iS50 FT-IR with an ATR attachment. The Ultraviolet-visible (UV-Vis) diffuse reflectance spectra were collected on a Shimadzu UV-2700 Spectrophotometer and BaSO4 was used as the reference material. The Raman spectra were recorded using Thermo Fisher DXRxi equipped with a 532 nm laser. The metal loading was measured by inductively coupled plasma atomic emission spectroscopy (ICP-AES; Perkin Elmer ICP Avio 500). N2 sorption isotherms were measured at 77 K on a Quantachrome Autosorb-iQ3 gas adsorption analyzer. The total specific surface area was calculated from the N2 adsorption branch in the range of relative pressure from 0.05 to 0.30 by the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method. Total pore volume was obtained at the P/P0 of 0.995. The pore size distribution was analyzed using the Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) method. Temperature-programmed reduction of hydrogen (H2-TPR) and temperature-programmed desorption of ammonia (NH3-TPD) experiments were carried out using a TP5080 multi-functional adsorption instrument (Xianquan Co., Ltd) with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). The electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) data were collected using Varian E112 spectrometer to analyze radical generation with 5,5-dimethyl-1-pyrroline N-oxide (DMPO) as the spin trapping agents. 2.4 Catalytic degradation testing Acid orange 7, neutral red, tetracycline hydrochloride, and oxytetracycline as model pollutants were used to investigate the Fenton-like degradation activity of the catalysts in this work. All experiments were performed using the desired concentration of catalyst (200 mg L−1), NaHCO3 (3.6 mM), and pollutant (50 mg L−1) in 250 mL deionized water at ∼pH 8, room temperature. Before the addition of H2O2, the solution was stirred in dark condition for 30 min to reach equilibrium adsorption. Then, the catalytic degradation of pollutants was initiated by adding H2O2 (60 mM) into the mixture. Aliquots of the aqueous samples (2 mL) were periodically withdrawn, filtered through 0.2 μm Millipore syringe filters. The concentrations of acid orange 7, neutral red, tetracycline hydrochloride, and oxytetracycline were immediately detected using Agilent Cary 60 UV-Vis spectrophotometer [29]. The Langmuir-Hinshelwood (L-H) model was used to quantify the degradation rate, as the apparent kinetic constant (k) follows a pseudo-first-order relationship [30]. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Chemical properties of the catalysts Spatially-resolved atom probe tomography (APT) technique was used to determine the Co spatial position and distribution with respective to Si and O atoms in the in Co-O-Si catalyst sample and sequentially reconstructing the atomic information into a 3D tomography. Fig. 2a shows the SEM image of the sharpened tip of the Co-O-Si sample prepared for the APT measurement. From the image of the 3D construct of the Co-O-Si sample as shown in Fig. 2b, the individual APT mapping of Si, O and Co atoms can be observed to be well dispersed throughout the selected sample, especially that the Co atoms are finely distributed without appreciable aggregation. Moreover, the Co atom distribution extracted from the 3D reconstruction image has a similar mapping detail and size resolution to those of the Si and O distributions signifying the excellent catalyst dispersion and atomic size. The transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and the fast Fourier transform (FFT) images depicted in Fig. 3a illustrate the highly amorphous nature of the Co-O-Si catalyst, devoid of metal aggregation and the presence of crystalline nanoparticles or phases. The absence of diffraction rings in the FFT inset further confirms the amorphouse structure of the material, suggesting no ordered crystalline cobalt oxide domains.The high-angle annular dark-field (HAADF) image in Fig. 3b, alongside the corresponding elemental mapping of Si, O and Co in Fig. 3c-e, demonstrates the well-dispersed nature of Co species within the Co-O-Si catalyst, consistent with the APT findings. The EDS elemental mapping of cobalt (Fig. 3e) shows a uniform distribution of Co species throughout the silica support, with no visible cobalt clusters or particles, suggesting that cobalt is atomically dispersed. The individual Co atoms can be appreciated by the bright spots in Fig. 3b, which is evidence of the amorphous structure and homogeneous single-atomic distribution of cobalt as confirmed by the corresponding elemental mapping in Fig. 3e. This interpretation is in good accord with previous studies where similar STEM-HAADF mapping was used to infer high dispersion of elements in amorphous matrices [31]. In contrast, the impregnated Co3O4/SiO2 catalyst, as shown in Fig. S2a, exhibits large, poorly dispersed, cobalt oxide nanoparticles on the support, with particle diameters ranging from 50 to 500 nm. Recent studies have highlighted the critical role of metal support interactions in stabilizing the single atoms and tuning their catalytic behavior. He et al. showed that well-regulated metal support interactions can have an impact on the electronic structure and binding strength of intermediates, which enhances catalytic activity. Their findings also emphasize that strong linkages between single atoms and support are crucial to prevent aggregation intel metal clusters, which is an essential requirement to maintain atomic dispersion [32]. Similarly, Cheng et al. showed that the local coordination environment and charge redistribution at the metal-support interface directly govern catalytic functionality and deactivation resistance in single atom systems [33]. In our Co-O-Si catalyst, the amorphous structure observed in Fig. 3a provides comparable benefits. The interactions between the cobalt metal and the silica support assist with suppressing aggregation and promoting efficient activation of hydrogen peroxide. The metal support interactions enhance the generation of hydroxyl radicals and enable efficient degradation of AO7. To determine the Co phase in the Co-O-Si catalyst, X-ray diffraction (XRD) analyses were conducted. Fig. 4 shows a broad peak centered at 10.4° 2θ for the Co-O-Si catalyst, with no diffraction peak associated with cobalt oxides indicating the predominantly amorphous nature of the bulk phase which are consistent with the TEM findings (Fig. 3a). Conversely, Co3O4/SiO2 exhibits strong diffraction peaks at 19.0, 31.3, 36.8, 44.8 and 59.4 2θ, which correspond to the dominant Co3O4 crystallites (JCPDS Card No. 76–1802). Notably,the broad peak at 10.4° 2θ of the Co-O-Si catalyst shows a substantial 0.5° 2θ shift toward higher angle as compared to that of the Co3O4/SiO2 and pure SiO2. This diffraction shift can be explained by the incorporation of atomic Co2+ into the SiO2 network causing lattice distortion, which is in similar agreement with another study showcasing Co/SBA-15 [34]. Similarly, earlier studies have shown that the incorporation of Co atoms into SiO2 networks can induce a longer bond length and change the 2θ value of the amorphous peak offering control of the size of the unit cell through careful selection of the sol-gel synthesis conditions, such as pH and cobalt precursors [34,35]. X-ray absorption fine structure (XAFS) analyses were conducted to further understand the atomic coordination and electronic shell configurations of the Co-O-Si catalyst. The X-ray absorption near-edge structure (XANES) spectra in Fig. 5a revealed that the intensity of peaks for Co-O-Si catalyst closely resembles that of CoO, but significantly different from the metallic Co and Co3O4, suggesting that the Co atoms in Co-O-Si catalyst carry a positive charge and the average oxidation state of Co is Co2+. Analysis of the Fourier-transformed (FT) k 3-weighted extended X-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS) spectrum for Co-O-Si catalyst in Fig. 5b revealed a dominant peak at 1.73 Å, corresponding to the Co-O coordination. Unlike metallic Co, CoO, and Co3O4, there is no Co-Co coordination peak observed in the Co-O-Si catalyst, providing strong evidence of its single-atom structure. Fitting of the Co K-edge EXAFS spectra using the Co-O scattering path from the CoO4 structure (Fig. 5c) yields a coordination number of 4.3 ± 0.6 (Table S1) for the first shell of Co atoms [36]. To examine the chemical properties and structure of Co-O-Si catalyst, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), fourier transform infrared-attenuated total reflectance (FTIR-ATR) and UV-Vis diffuse reflectance spectroscopy (DRS) techniques were carried out. The XPS spectrum of Co 2p in Fig. 6a shows two peaks at 782.2 eV and 798.1 eV for Co-O-Si catalyst, corresponding to the Co2+ oxidation state of Co 2p3/2 and Co 2p1/2 respectively [37,38], consistent with the XANES results. Conversely, additional peaks at 794.7 eV and 779.7 eV suggest that Co3O4/SiO2 catalyst contains both Co2+ and Co3+ oxidation states. This difference is expected due to the distinct structural environments of cobalt in the two different catalysts. In Co3O4, cobalt exists in 2 + and 3 + oxidation states in a mixed valence spinel oxide structure, whereas in Co-O-Si, cobalt atoms are atomically dispersed within the silica support and predominantly exist as Co2+. Furthermore, O 1 s spectra (Fig. S3) of Co-O-Si, exhibits Co-O-Si, Si-OH, Si-O-Si, and Co-OH peaks. In contrast, the Co-O-Si peak at 534.5 eV is absent in the Co3O4/SiO2, while a significantly new Co-O-Co peak is evidenced at 529.8 eV [39,40]. Similarly, FTIR-ATR spectra shown in Fig. 6b shows that all three samples (SiO2, Co3O4/SiO2 and Co-O-Si) possess a strong vibration band at 1032 cm−1 with a shoulder band at 1193 cm−1, which are ascribed to the asymmetric stretching vibration of the Si-O-Si bonds bridging the SiO4 structural units [41–43]. Another common feature is the band at 799 cm−1, ascribed to the symmetric stretching vibration of the Si-O-Si network [43]. Upon close inspection, the Co-O-Si catalyst spectrum shows an additional shoulder band at 925 cm−1, which is due to the strong vibrational interaction between the Co2+ ions and the Si-O− siloxanes in the Co-O-Si structure [44,45]. This shoulder band is absent in both the Co3O4/SiO2 and in the SiO2 spectra. It is also noteworthy that two additional strong bands at 660 and 558 cm−1 are shown in the Co3O4/SiO2 spectrum, which are attributed to the Co3O4 species [41,46]. These results are further supported by UV-Vis DRS in Fig. 6c, which shows the Co-O-Si catalyst produced triplet peaks with maxima at 523, 586, and 651 nm, resulting from the Co2+ ions in a tetrahedral environment [47,48], which corroborated with the fitting of the Co K-edge EXAFS spectra (Fig. 5c). In contrast, the Co3O4/SiO2 shows a completely different spectrum with two broad reflection bands at 349 and 694 nm, which are characteristics of the Co3O4 phase [42,49,50]. The first band is due to the presence of ligand to metal charge transfer transition of O2-→Co2+, while the second band is indicative of O2-→Co3+ charge transfer transition [50]. These findings are further affirmed by the Raman spectroscopy whereby these bands are characteristic peaks of Co3O4 found in the Co3O4/SiO2, of which are absent in the Co-O-Si catalyst (Fig. S4) [51]. 3.2 Catalytic performance The obtained Co-O-Si catalyst was comprehensively evaluated for degradation of acid orange 7 (AO7), neutral red, oxytetracycline and tetracycline hydrochloride, which are commonly known for their persistent, hazardous nature in the environment. The normalized results (after discounting dark adsorption capacity; not shown) are compared with pure Co3O4 and SiO2-supported Co3O4 catalysts. As shown in Fig. 7a, the Co3O4 catalyst exhibited the lowest activity, which can only degrade 39 % of AO7 organic dye followed by 45 % for Co3O4/SiO2 and a near 100 % for Co-O-Si after 60 min. In Fig. 7b, the catalytic activity is expressed as the apparent kinetic constant (k) using the Langmuir-Hinshelwood (L-H) model [29,52], among which Co3O4 catalyst showed the lowest kinetic rate of 0.014 min−1. Co3O4/SiO2 was effective in improving the degradation efficiency to a small extent (k = 0.017 min−1), achieving a 21 % enhancement in the k value. In contrast, the Co-O-Si catalyst showed a remarkable enhancement with a 97 % of AO7 removal in the first 2.5 min, and the highest k value of 1.4 min−1, which is two orders of magnitude higher than that of the Co3O4 and the Co3O4/SiO2 catalysts. In order to evaluate the Co utilization efficiency, AO7 degradation was evaluated as a function of the Co-O-Si catalyst concentration. It was observed that even 5 mg L−1 of the catalyst can degrade 98 % of AO7 after 30 min (Fig. S5). Importantly, the Co-O-Si catalyst also showed good catalyst reusability without any appreciable activity reduction over 5 runs (Fig. 7c) with a comparable k value (k = 1.1 ± 0.2 min−1). In addition, the Co-O-Si catalyst demonstrated good universal applicability for neutral red (NR) and two other common, broad-spectrum antibiotics (oxytetracycline (OTC) and tetracycline hydrochloride (TCH)) as shown in Fig. 7d. In fact, the k value decreases in the order of AO7 > TCH > NR > OTC, which warrants further comprehensive investigation into reaction optimization. When comparing with the existing literature, the degradation performance and universal applicability for organic pollutant removal are comparable, and superior to most of the state-of-the-art Co-based Fenton-like catalysts (Table S2) and SACs (Table S3). For example, 91 % of TCH was degraded by the Co-O-Si catalyst after 30 min with a high k value of 0.31 min−1 (Fig. 7d and Table S2), which is comparable with the CoN/N-C@SiO2 catalyst [53], notwithstanding five times higher TCH concentration was employed in our work. Another work of Co pCN catalyst achieved a 98 % removal of TC in a 60 mins duration but with TC concentration 2.5 times lower than our work (Table S3 [54]). Table S3 also shows that our Co-O-Si catalyst was able to achieve the highest metal loading amount in comparison to the other single atom catalysts synthesized, which is a key property to its excellent performance. Table 1 shows the catalyst performance, textural properties and loading per weight percent. Texturally, Co-O-Si demonstrated a Type I microporous structure with the highest surface area (141.6 m2g−1), followed by Type II Co3O4 (surface area = 35.3 m2g−1), and Type IV Co3O4/SiO2 (surface area = 5.2 m2g−1). The results obtained from inductively coupled plasma atomic emission spectroscopy (ICP-AES) indicate that the loading of Co in the Co-O-Si catalyst reached up to 16.3 wt% (Table 1) marking the highest reported loading for a Co catalyst, while the Co3O4/SiO2 sample had a slightly higher cobalt loading of 18.9 wt% (Table 1). This remarkable performance of the Co-O-Si single atom catalyst can be attributed to two folds; (1) catalyst properties and (2) material structure. Due to its higher catalyst dispersion and distribution, as well as an increased overall surface area and microporosity, it provides more accessible active sites for the oxidation of peroxide to occur, leading to an increased radical production and pollutant degradation efficiency. The catalytic degradation of AO7 using the Co-O-Si catalyst is strongly dependant on the textural properties of the material, including surface area and pore volume. Adsorption of the pollutant is a prerequisite for effective catalytic oxidation, as it brings the reactant molecules in close proximity to the active sites of the catalyst and facilitates subsequent radical attack. Ding et al., reported that there is a positive correlation between the rate constant (k) and both the BET surface area and the pore volume, indicating that materials with higher surface accessibility perform better [31]. This trend is consistent with our results and the idea that higher surface area allows (i) better adsorption of the pollutant molecules, (ii) improved diffusion and interaction of hydrogen peroxide with the active sites present within the Co-O-Si catalyst, and (iii) more efficient generation of radicals using hydrogen peroxide [55]. When AO7 molecules are adsorbed near or directly onto the catalytic sites where radicals are generated, the degradation becomes more effective due to the reduced distance between the reactant and the oxidizing agent. Moreover, the pore volume contributes not only by increasing the accessible surface area but also by enhancing the mass transfer within the catalyst structure. This facilitates faster diffusion of both the AO7 molecules and hydrogen peroxide into the porous network which allows efficient access to the active sites within the Co-O-Si catalyst. As previously reported in the literature, materials with a broader mesoporous structure benefit from improved mass transfer rates that can accelerate the oxidant activation and pollutant degradation [56]. While our system utilizes hydrogen peroxide instead of peroxymonosulfate (PMS) and targets AO7, the principle is the same: better pore connectivity and volume promotes catalytic efficiency by reducing transport limitations and ensuring that the reactants are rapidly delivered to the active sites. Microscopic and spectroscopic analyses conducted in this study revealed minimal metal aggregation, with cobalt ions seamlessly integrated into the silica network to form the Co-O-Si configuration. The well-dispersed and atomic size control can be attributed to the effective dispersion of cobalt ions facilitated by the highly hydrolyzed ES40 polymer during the sol-gel synthesis process and subsequent rapid thermal treatment (RTP). In our previous studies [52,57,58], the long chains of hydrolyzed ES40 gave rise to fractal-like, branched polymeric structure with robust network rigidity that enabled the cobalt ions to be isolated, while the RTP ensures fast anchoring of Co atoms, which are rapidly incorporated into the SiO2 matrix to form the Co-O-Si coordination. Furthermore, our previous work demonstrated that using ES40 as SiO2 precursor with RTP can facilitate and improve the Co catalyst dispersion compared to tetraethyl orthosilicate (TEOS) and a slow conventional thermal process [52]. However, in that previous study, a small portion of crystalline Co3O4 nanoparticles measuring 5 nm in diameter are still observed in the as-synthesized Co3O4/SiO2 nanocomposite due to metal aggregation. To further improve the Co dispersion, hydrolysis of ES40 was enhanced in this work by increasing the HNO3 concentration to accelerate the acid-catalyzed hydrolysis reaction during the sol-gel process. These results show that highly hydrolyzed ES40 is favorable for isolating the cobalt(II) ions and predisposed the cobalt(II) ions to be atomically coordinated with the hydrolyzed silicic groups. Subsequently, the Co-O-Si group rapidly consolidated through a fast thermal treatment and forms an integrated Co-O-Si configuration without any Co-Co bonding as confirmed by XAFS, UV-Vis DRS, and FTIR results as well as without any cobalt oxides nanoparticles by HR-TEM and APT analyses. Furthermore, temperature-programmed desorption of ammonia (NH3-TPD; Fig. S7a) was conducted to assess the presence of tetrahedrally coordinated Co2+ in the Co-O-Si catalyst. This method is commonly used for measuring the surface acidity of porous materials such as zeolites, clays, or porous silica. It is anticipated that the presence of tetrahedrally coordinated Co2+ in the Co-O-Si structure possess some degree of acidity due to the acidic sites on the Co2+ ions. This is demonstrated by a broad desorption peak centered at 384 ℃ in Fig. S7a, which is not observed in the Co3O4/SiO2 and in the SiO2 temperature profiles. The presence of acidic sites in the Co-O-Si sample can significantly improve the catalytic activity which can be observed in Fig. 7a, as they can facilitate the activation of reactant molecules. The sites can act as active centers where reactants can bind more effectively, which leads to improved interactions and reaction kinetics. As a result, the Co-O-Si sample exhibited a superior degradation performance in comparison to the SiO2 sample and the Co3O4/SiO2 sample. Similarly, temperature-programmed reduction of hydrogen (H2-TPR; Fig. S7b) was used to assess the redox stability of Co-O-Si sample in comparison to the Co3O4/SiO2. The absence of peaks between 100 and 700 ℃ in the H2-TPR curve for the Co-O-Si catalyst, contrasting with the two distinct peaks observed for the Co3O4/SiO2 catalyst at 399 ℃ and 471 ℃, indicates the stable bonding of single Co within the Co-O-Si network structure. This stability persisted under reductive H2 conditions across the examined temperature range, underscoring the robust nature of the Co-O-Si catalyst. The stable bonding of single Co atoms within the Co-O-Si network is likely a key factor contributing to the excellent reusability observed during the reusability testing (Fig. 7c). From the reusability testing results, it can be observed that the Co-O-Si sample maintained its activity over 5 runs with no significant reduction in the performance. The results demonstrate promising material stability of the single Co atoms embedded in the Co-O-Si structure, making it a durable catalyst for repeated use. 3.3 Mechanistic insight The degradation results further prompted a mechanistic study of the formation of radicals mduring the degradation reaction. Electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) spectroscopy was used to analyze the radicals formed in the reaction solutions with 5,5-dimethyl-1-pyrroline (DMPO) as the spin trapping agent and 2-hydroxy-5,5-dimethyl-1-pyrroline-N-oxide (HDMPO), which is also formed when DMPO oxidizes via DMPO-OH [59]. Fig. 8 shows the presence of hydroxyl (•OH) and perhydroxyl radicals (•O2H) and their relative concentrations in the reaction solutions of the three catalysts (Co-O-Si, Co3O4/SiO2, Co3O4) [60–64]. The relative signal intensity of radicals in the spectra demonstrates that the Co-O-Si catalyst contains a much higher level of radical species compared to Co3O4/SiO2 and Co3O4, which is consistent with the kinetic rates of the catalysts during pollutant degradation. From the first derivative analysis of area under the curves, Co-O-Si was able to produce 2.77 and 2.85 times more radicals compared to Co3O4/SiO2 and Co3O4 catalysts respectively. Given that the degradation process follows a pseudo first order kinetics, the significant increase in the kinetic constant for Co-O-Si can be attributed to its enhanced ability to generate reactive radicals. Therefore, more radicals are available to interact and break down the pollutant models as observed by Co-O-Si. It is clear that the enhanced radical generation of Co-O-Si is directly corelated with high surface area, good catalyst dispersion; spatially and atomically, to provide the exposed Co sites with an excellent Co2+/Co3+ regeneration cycle. In fact, this catalyst has shown the capacity to regenerate and continue to produce significant radical concentration responsible for the excellent reusability and degradation over 5 reuse cycles. This confirms that Co-O-Si catalyst has achieved a superior catalytic efficiency and stability without loss of activity for the degradation of the pollutants studied in this paper. Notwithstanding, other types of radicals such as superoxide ion radicals (•O2 −), singlet oxygen (1O2), and carbonate radicals (•CO3 −) can also be generated in this activated peroxymonocarbonate (APMC) process, but are limited to the detection sensitivity and timescale of the EPR technique due to a much shorter half-life and in much lower concentrations [52,60]. While singlet oxygen is a potential ROS, several studies have shown that its direct detection via EPR is limited. The work carried out by Wang et al. showed that TEMP, which is the trapping agent for singlet oxygen radical, failed to produce detectable signals, and subsequent scavenger experiments confirmed no significant role of singlet oxygen radical [65]. Likewise, another study reported noted challenges in distinguishing the DMPO-.O2 - adduct due to overlapping peak structures and solvent effects [66]. Therefore, in this work, DMPO was employed to detect the hydroxyl and per hydroxyl radicals. Moreover, DMPO has been found to offer more reliable detection than other probes under the studied conditions [67]. These considerations along with the excellent degradation kinetics and reusability performance of Co-O-Si suggest that the degradation proceeds predominantly via a hydroxyl radical-mediated mechanism. (1) Si-O-Co2+ + H2O2 → Si-O-Co3+ + •OH (2) Si-O-Co3+ + H2O2 → Si-O-Co2+ + •O2H According to previous studies on Fenton-like, heterogeneous cobalt catalysis via the APMC process (Table S2) [44,52], the radicals can easily diffuse away from the catalyst surface back into the bulk solution due to the porous silica network. Then, the radicals proceed to rapidly attack the AO7 in the bulk solution and break down the by-products into 1,4 benzenediol, 1,2-naphthoquinone, and sulfanilic acid (Fig. S8), which eventually will demineralize into CO2 and H2O [38]. As shown in [Eq. (1)], the Si-O-Co2+ reacts with H2O2 to generate •OH and oxidizes to form Si-O-Co3+ [68–70]. The oxidized Si-O-Co3+ can then be reduced by H2O2 to regenerate Si-O-Co2+, leading to the production of •O2H [Eq. (2)]. 4 Conclusion In conclusion, an effective strategy was developed for the synthesis of SiO2-supported Co single-atom catalyst. The Co atoms were strongly incorporated into the SiO2 network by Co-O-Si configuration with good thermal and reductive stability. The Co maintained atomic dispersion with ultrahigh Co loading amount of 16.3 wt% while no metal aggregation was detected. The obtained Co-O-Si catalyst showed superior degradation activity for a wide range of hazardous organic pollutants in advanced wastewater treatment, which achieved 97 % of AO7 degradation within 2.5 min. Owing to the rapid radical generation and catalyst regeneration, the degradation kinetic rate was two orders of magnitude higher than those of the Co3O4 nano catalyst, and Co-impregnated silica catalysts. Moreover, the atomically dispersed Co showed an enhanced Co3+/Co2+ regeneration cycle and outstanding reusability. The results demonstrate that the sol-gel/RTP combined strategy is highly efficient for designing ultrahigh-loading, single-atom Co catalysts using a versatile SiO2 platform to achieve superior Fenton-like catalysis and potentially other catalytic reactions involving cobalt. coredata.dc:description: Single-atom catalysts (SACs) have generated a significant research interest due to the enormous potential of being able to maximize the catalytic activity and efficiency. One synthetic strategy to control the dispersion, loading and surface area of catalyst to enhance catalyst performance is to design a heterogeneous, SAC system. However, the mechanistic control and understanding of catalyst dispersion, size distribution, and stability within a suitable support remains challenging. In this paper, a new strategy was developed for the synthesis of Fenton-like, Co-O-Si SAC by combining sol-gel chemistry and rapid thermal processing for catalytic metal-center anchoring. A high amount of Co metal loading of 16.3 wt% was achieved in a well-integrated, single atom Co-O-Si framework possessing excellent metal ion dispersion without any metal aggregation or metal oxides formation. The obtained Co-O-Si SAC delivered two orders of magnitude higher catalytic activity compared to the other cobalt-based, Fenton nanoparticle catalysts with outstanding reusability and performance stability for the removal of hazardous organic compounds using model antibiotics (oxytetracycline, tetracycline hydrochloride) and synthetic dyes (neutral red, acid orange).
